data: If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 9 steps left. Take 10 steps forward. Take 9 steps right. Take 10 steps backward. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.

The basic axis for walking is forward. A person with 5 sets of 2 and repeating this sequence can walk backwards by repeating 10 steps forward. There is an axis based on the human body that always points forward. So, the answer is No.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 4 steps. Turn around. Take 4 steps. Turn around. Turn right. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
Turn right is not an identical action as taking 4 steps. So, the answer is Yes.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 6 steps. Take 4 steps. Turn around. Take 10 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.

Turn around is a reversal and return is a turn. If you only take 6 steps you are back 6 steps. If you take 4 steps and you turn around 5 steps you are back 6 steps. If you only take 4 steps, you are back 4 steps. If you take 10 steps and you turn around 10 steps you are back 10 steps. So, the answer is Yes.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 7 steps. Take 1 step. Take 7 steps. Turn left. Take 5 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
Take 1 step and turn right. Similarly, take one step and turn left. So, the answer is No.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 10 steps. Turn left. Turn left. Take 9 steps. Take 3 steps. Take 3 steps. Turn around. Take 5 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
One must turn left. The order in which you take steps varies between ones direction: turn left. Then take 7 steps, then take 10 steps. No.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Turn left. Turn right. Take 7 steps. Turn around. Take 7 steps. Turn right. Turn left. Turn right. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
Turn around. Take 7 steps. Turn right. Take 7 steps. Turn left. Take 7 steps. Turn right. Take 7 steps. So, the answer is No.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 8 steps. Take 9 steps. Turn right. Turn right. Take 8 steps. Take 9 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
Twice a step equals 3 steps. Twice a step equals 6 steps. Twice a step equals 9 steps. If you take 8 steps and take 9 steps first, you return to take 8 steps and 9 steps. So, the answer is Yes.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 6 steps. Turn around. Take 8 steps. Take 2 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
If you take 6 steps, and turn around 2 times, you take 8 steps - 2 steps return to the starting point. The answer is No.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 1 step left. Take 4 steps forward. Take 6 steps forward. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
When you take 4 steps back you’re walking forward. When you take 6 steps forward, you’re going backward. The first instructions always say to face forward. So, the answer is Yes.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 3 steps. Take 9 steps. Turn around. Take 2 steps. Take 7 steps. Take 3 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
One has to start in the same position as the original starting point to complete the instructions. So, the answer is Yes.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 1 step backward. Take 1 step backward. Take 1 step backward. Take 3 steps forward. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
The instructions above are all about facing forward. The only part the person does not take one step backward is after an extra step forward. So, the answer is No.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 6 steps backward. Take 8 steps right. Take 1 step backward. Take 5 steps left. Take 2 steps left. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.

Once you get to the starting point, always facing forward, take the steps you took backwards in reverse. This is the same as if you were facing forward. To take 6 steps backward, take one step backward and then step 1 backwards. To take 5 steps left, take 2 steps left and then take 6 steps backward. To take 2 steps left, take 3 steps left and then take 3 steps backwards. So, the answer is Yes.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 9 steps left. Take 10 steps left. Take 3 steps left. Take 1 step left. Take 3 steps backward. Take 6 steps left. Take 3 steps forward. Take 4 steps right. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
Steps left always point towards the starting point. Steps backward is when you take steps backward in a direction that is in the opposite direction you are going. So, the answer is No.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 4 steps left. Take 3 steps forward. Take 1 step right. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
If someone always has to face forward, they’ re always facing forward. If you turn your head back, you’ ll be facing towards the starting point. So, the answer is Yes.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 3 steps right. Take 1 step backward. Take 6 steps left. Take 1 step forward. Take 3 steps right. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.

A person always begins the exercise facing forward and if the number of steps increases, the starting point will be backward. The first step forward is always forward. If one takes 6 steps left, one is taken backward. The answer: Yes.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Turn right. Turn right. Turn around. Turn left. Take 4 steps. Take 10 steps. Take 8 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.

Just because you went around your step doesn’t mean you took 10 steps. Turning right is the same as going around your step. Putting your right foot down on any part of your step and walking your way back to the starting point would result in you returning back to the starting point. So, the answer is no.

When you take 6 steps you are on the return route for the first 9 steps. So, the answer is Yes.

Turn around takes 9 steps. Turn right takes 3 steps. So, the answer is Yes.

It goes down one step, then back up, then up again, then right. So, the answer is Yes.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Turn right. Take 1 step. Take 7 steps. Take 1 step. Take 5 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
The first step will take you away from the starting point. The second step will take you back. So, the answer is No.

First find your path from the starting point and the location should be at the end of the first step as well. So, the answer is No.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 5 steps. Take 3 steps. Take 2 steps. Turn around. Take 10 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
The instructions assume all of the steps are straight and there is an ending point somewhere. The starting point is not the end of the journey. So, the answer is Yes.
If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Take 3 steps. Take 7 steps. Turn around. Take 10 steps. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.
The only steps that return to something starting from a place that you start are the steps you take to arrive at the place you started. So, the answer is Yes.

If you follow these instructions, do you return to the starting point? Always face forward. Take 7 steps left. Take 2 steps right. Take 5 steps backward. Take 8 steps left. Take 7 steps forward. Take 7 steps right. Take 9 steps forward. Options: - Yes - No Let’ s think step by step.

If you face forward you go 5 steps backwards. If you face backwards the entire sequence repeats itself 6 times, ending with 2 steps right. A sequence repeated 6 times, ending with 2 steps left. Using the same sequence demonstrates that you are going left on the left. This implies that you are going at a consistent walking pace. So, the answer is yes.

There is an object (your face) at the place where all steps are taken. The object is the starting point. So, the answer is Yes.

If you walk back to where you started, you would take 4 steps back to the starting point. So, the answer is yes.

If you always face forward, you would always be in the forward position. There is an initial step of 6 steps left, and you go 6 steps straight, and there are 6 steps right. So, the answer is no.

You cannot turn right and take 5 steps every way, you always come back. So, the answer is Yes.

If one always faces forward and takes 2 steps backward, then they take 2 steps back and 0 steps forward. These 8 steps would mean that one takes 3 steps back and 1 step forward. So, the answer is Yes.

Take 1 step. In one sequence of steps, you will be returning to the beginning point. If you follow the instructions, you will not take multiple sequences of steps but would return to the starting point. So, the answer is No.

9 steps are 9 miles. To turn around is to walk back to where you started. So, the answer is yes.

In the first illustration the person was facing forward, the ending instructions have the person facing backward. The second illustration is a step backward, a last action is to take 3 steps left. The answer: No.

The first two instructions return to the same starting point. The final step is to take 4 steps, to do it the usual way. So, the answer is yes.

You are going to always face forward. If you take 5 steps backward, you are walking backward. If you take 4 steps backward, you are walking forward. The first two actions represent two directions. So, the answer is No.

You can back up to the starting point by starting from a starting place and returning the same way. The starting point is facing forward and returns at the same point. In the first step, you always face forward. You don’t move to the right or to the left. If you move to the left, you move to the right. If you move to the right, you move to the left. You cannot return back to the starting point. So, the answer is No.
